docs.lead_paragraph: AT 9 o'clock on a recent Monday morning, during a demonstration in a Byram Hills High School driver's- education class, 17-year-old Nancy Hoffmann blew into a small, hand-held black device that resembles a transistor radio but is actually an Alco-Sensor preliminary breath-tester. Three hundred of these instruments have recently been purchased by the county to help the county and local police find and arrest drunk drivers. Nancy was being tested as part of an experiment with the equipment at the Armonk school. The machine reported a blood alcohol content that registered .22 on its scale, twice the amount needed to be arrested for drunk driving, although Nancy had taken nothing stronger than mouthwash, which can deceive the machine into giving positive readings for a few minutes.
